The reasons given, as well as others which arise from a detailed compar-ison between the two, point to a common use of the same sources, rather than to a direct bon-owing of the one historian from the other. But they must have dealt with these in different fashion, Livy keeping close to the early narrative in its fuller form, while the edition which Polybius gives is a summary and corrected one. It rema-ins then to ascertain, if possible, the nature of these common sources.
